required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Enteral Iron Supplementation in Critical Illness
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of the Effects of Enteral Iron Supplementation on Anemia and Risk of Infection in Critical Illness

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

clinical_study.source: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the efficacy of enteral iron supplementation for improving anemia, decreasing the risk of blood transfusion, and decreasing mortality in patients who are hospitalized in the intensive care unit. This study will also address any relationship between enteral iron supplementation and risk of infection.

detailed_description.textblock: Critical illness is characterized by the anemia of inflammation, which is partially caused by sequestration of iron from bone marrow sites of erythropoiesis into storage within the reticuloendothelial system as ferritin. Also the majority of critically ill patients are hypoferremia, the efficacy of iron supplementation remains unknown. Furthermore, several retrospective studies have found an association between iron overload and infection. However, the relative risk/benefit profile of enteral iron supplementation with respect to infection has not been studied. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of enteral iron supplementation in critically ill patients. The hypothesis is that enteral iron supplementation will result in both an improved hematocrit and a decreased need for blood transfusion, without increasing the risk of infection.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects That Received at Least One RBC Transfusion During Admission to the Hospital
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout hospital stay up to 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects That Incurred at Least One Infection Throughout Hospital Admission
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout hospital stay up to 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Instance of Drug-related Constipation Throughout Hospital Admission
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout hospital stay up to 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Average Number of Days That Subjects Were Taking Antibiotics
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout hospital stay up to 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Hospital Mortality, as Measured by Number of Subject Deaths While Admitted to Hospital
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout hospital stay up to 6 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Average Length of Stay in the Hospital
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout hospital stay up to 6 weeks

arm_group.description: Ferrous sulfate 325 mg either by capsule or oral solution three times a day at 9 am, 1pm and 5 pm until hospital discharge or for 42 days, whichever occurs first.
Placebo capsule three times a day at 9 am, 1pm and 5 pm until hospital discharge or for 42 days, whichever occurs first.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age > 18 years
- Anemia (Hemoglobin < 13.0 g/dL)
- â‰¤ 72 hours from hospital admission
- Current tolerance of enteral medications
- Expected ICU LOS > 5 days
Exclusion Criteria:
- Active bleeding
- Chronic inflammatory disease
- End-stage renal disease
- Hematologic disorders
- Macrocytic anemia
- Current use of erythropoietin
- Pregnancy
- Prohibition of RBC transfusions
- Moribund state in which death is imminent
- Enrollment in another clinical trial

measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

measure.title: Baseline hematocrit
measure.units: % of RBC in total blood volume

measure.title: Admission APACHE II
measure.description: Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE): Designed to measure the severity of disease for adult patients admitted to intensive care units. The point score is calculated from a patient's age and 12 routine physiological measurements: alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient or arterial blood gasses, temperature, mean arterial pressure, pH arterial, heart rate, respiratory rate, sodium (serum), potassium (serum), creatinine, hematocrit, white blood cell count, glasgow coma scale. The APACHE score ranges from 0 to 71, with 0 indicating a higher mortality risk and 71 a lower risk.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
